div1.p: MARYLAND IN MEDICINE

Address Of Dr. V. M. Reichard At
Blue Mountain House.
CUMBERLAND VALLEYDOCTORS

They Meet And Have A Banquet--
Dr. Reichard Tells Of Achieve-
ments Of His Profession In State.
[Special Dispatch to the Baltimore Sun.]

Blue Mountain, Md., Sept. 6.--The sec-
ond annual meeting of the Cumberland Val-
ley Medical Association was held at the
Blue Mountain House today. Many physi-
cians from Maryland and Southern Pennsyl-
vania were present. A business session pre-
sided over by Dr. R. W. Ramsey, of Cham-
bersburg, was held this morning.

The following officers were elected: Presi-
dent, Dr. V. M. Reichard, Fairplay, Md.:
vice-presidents, Dr. J. W. Humrichouse,
Hagerstown; Dr. T. H. Weagley, Marion,
Pa.; Dr. A. R. Allen, Carlisle, Pa.; secre-
tary, Dr. J. J. Kaufman, Scotland, Pa.; as-
sistant secretaries, Dr. J. H. McCreary,
Shippensburg, Pa.; Dr. D. B. Montgomery,
Chambersburg, Pa.; Dr. D. C. R. Miller,
State Line, Pa.; treasurer, Dr. J. J. Koser,
Shippensburg, Pa.

Dr. D. C. R. Miller, State Line, read a
paper on “Pulmonary Hemorrhages.” Dr.
Guy L. Hunner, of Baltimore, a guest, read
a paper on “A Disease Peculiar to Women.”

Dr. A. R. Allen, of Carlisle, read a paper
on “The Importance of Early Operation in
Intestinal Obstructions.”

A banquet was held tonight. Dr. James
E. Pilcher, of Carlisle, was toastmaster.
Dr. Thomas B. Johnson, of Frederick, was
a guest. The society decided to meet next
year in September at Mount Holly Springs,
Cumberland county, Pa.

The principal address was made at the
banquet by Dr. V. M. Reichard, of Fair-
play, one of the leading physicians of Wash-
ington county. Dr. Reichard said in part:

"Every citizen of Maryland has a just
pride in her renown. To every department
she has contributed her proportion of men
and deeds, and in some she stands peerless.
And when we turn to medicine we find her
abreast with the very first and taking a
position of enviable brilliancy. During the
Colonial and Revolutionary periods her
medical men stood for what was highest
and best in their profession. Charles Fred-
erick Wiesenthal, of Baltimore Town,
though born in Prussia, entered with all
the zeal of ardent patriotism into the de-
fense of his adopted country. Surgeon to
Smallwood's Marylanders, he became Sur-
geon-General of the State and surgeon-in-
charge of the military hospitals at Balti-
more. In 1785 and 1786 he, assisted by Dr.
Ellsha John Hall, of Frederick county, led
a crusade to uplift the profession. They
proposed a paid board of examiners. The
first attempt to organize the State was
made in December, 1788, when a meeting
was held and Dr. Wiesenthal was elected
president.
Medical And Chirurgical Society.

"The Medical Society was short lived and
fell to pieces in 1790. But the work had
begun, seed had been sown, and the leaven
was at work. In due time the proper re-
sult was manifest and in 1799 the State
Medical Society was organized under the
name of the Medical and Chirurgical Fac-
ulty of Maryland, and it has continued
ever since. Thus Maryland became the
seventh in the Union to have a State so-
ciety. The physicians of the State re-
sponded to the call for a State meeting and
the gathering was in every sense repre-
sentative. Annapolis furnished the presi-
dent, Upton Scott, a man of fine, not to
say imposing, presence. The last survivor
of that worthy company was Dr. Ashton
Alexander, who died in Baltimore in 1855.

"One of the striking features of the
meeting was the prominence of the county
men. These men had grown up learning
from hard necessity to depend upon them-
selves; and they were well able to take
care of themselves. From my own county
of Washington came five--Zachariah Clag-
gett, of Pleasant Valley, the progenitor of
a line of distinguished physicians: Richard
Pindell, who was born in Hagerstown and
served in the First Maryland Regiment un-
der Col. Otho Holland Williams, and after-
ward moved to Lexington, Ky., where he
was the medical attendant of Henry Clay,
his brother-in-law; the others were Jacob
Schnively, Peter Waltz and Samuel Young.
Charles Alexander Warfield.

"Among this celebrated company at An-
napolis there was one who was in the full
flood of matured manhood, but whose
utation which is practically the medical
history of Maryland, so closely was he
identified with all that was important in
that history. The principles of surgery
came to him as the result of his thorough
knowledge of anatomy and his finely ma-
tured and cultivated judgment, and it was
no misnomer that the French surgeons
should style him during a Continental trip
which he made in 1867 ‘the Nestor of sur-
gery in America.’ And I sum up all that
was great, all that was noble, all that was
best in medicine in Maryland for half a
century when I name that ‘old emperor,’
Nathan Ryno Smith.
Jesse W. Lazear.

“Nathan R. Smith had 11 years to live
yet when in Towson, Md., Jesse W. Lazear
was born. He was graduated from the aca-
demic department of the Johns Hopkins
University in 1880. As the medical school
was not yet open, he went to New York for
his medical education, graduating from
the College of Physicians and Surgeons in
1893.” He gave special attention later to
bacteriology, studying abroad and at the
Johns Hopkins and working in Professor
Osler's clinic as his assistant. When the
United States Government decided to send
a commission to Cuba in 1900 under Dr.
Walter Reed to study yellow fever Lazear
enthusiastically joined the party and ren-
dered most valuable service, studying the
blood of many cases and helping materially
to reach the conclusion which has led to
the ridding of Havana of yellow fever and
thereby protecting the United States. The
commission had formulated, but not yet
published, its hypothesis that the mosquito
is an important factor in the causation of
yellow fever and that by preventing the
bite of the mosquito you prevent yellow fe-
ver. Inoculation experiments had proved
the truth of this hypothesis, and Lazear
knew it.

“While working in the yellow-fever hos-
pital he noticed a mosquito alight on his
hand and begin operations. Knowing that
this in all probability meant yellow fever
to him and great danger, he elected to prove
the theory for all time and deliberately al-
lowed the mosquito to fill itself. A brush
with his hand, a breath, could at any time
have chased the insect away. But this
hero, as brave a man as ever led a forlorn
hope, deliberately took his chances. In a
few days he took ill, rapidly developed a
very severe type of yellow fever and died,
sealing with his life the truth of the theory
he had helped to formulate. The anuals of
medicine afford no nobler exhibiton of he-
roic daring than this shown by Maryland's
devoted son.”

earlier career had been so brilliant as to
demand mention. Charles Alexander War-
field was the first in his State to propose
separation from the mother country, and
when the attempt was made to land tea
at Annapolis from the Peggy Stewart it was
this brilliant young leader of men who,
backed up by his neighbors of Anne Arun-
del, lined up before the house of the owner
of the vessel and compelled him to accept
one of two propositions--either to himself
apply the torch to his own vessel or to
hang before his own door. It did not take
long to reach a decision.
The University Of Maryland.

"Such was the material of which the
State society was composed. And, as one
would expect, the association at once took
high ground. Very early they arranged for
an examining and licensing board and as-
sumed control of the teaching of medicine
in the State. Later on they actually or-
ganized and put into operation a medical
college, which in a few years became a
university, and has since December 29,
1812, been known as the University of
Maryland.

"The latter part of the eighteenth cen-
tury saw the country full of smallpox.
Jenner had not yet-paved the way for pre-
vention and all that could be hoped for
was mitigation by inoculation. In this
practice Maryland was well to the front.
Adam Thompson introduced the so-called
American method of inoculation, and wrote
a tract on the subject which was printed
by Franklin in 1730 and ran through sev-
eral editions. In 1763 Henry Stevenson
was styled ‘the most successful inoculator
in America.’
Dr. John Crawford A Pioneer.

"While these men recognized the value
of the method, they saw its weakness in
that it always kept the disease alive. And
when something better was offered they
seized it with characteristic readiness. In
1798 Jenner published his first paper on
prevention of smallpox by vaccination,
and in 1800 Dr. John Crawford, of Balti-
more, made the first vaccination in Mary-
land with virus he had received from Lon-
don. The man who did most, however, to
establish vaccination in Maryland was Dr.
James Smith, who may properly be called
‘the father of vaccination in Maryland.’
He used it in the almshouse and wherever
it was possible to secure consent to its use.
So advanced was the position of Mary-
land in the matter of vaccination that she
stands even with Massachusetts and sec-
ond to none, being ahead of New York,
Pennsylvania and Virginia. A vaccine in-
stitute was founded in 1802, being the
second in America.

"Time does not suffice to trace minutely
the course and the events of medicine in
Maryland during the following years. The
University of Maryland has continued its
sessions regularly ever since, and now num-
bers over 5,000 alumni. Other schools have
been founded and there are now six medi-
cal schools in the State which have an
aggregate of nearly 10,000 graduates.

"The latter 80s and early 90s marked a
veritable renaissance in medicine. Johns
Hopkins Hospital was opened in 1880 and
the Medical School in 1893.

"As good work is being done by the
Maryland schools as is done anywhere in
America, and on some lines Maryland leads
all the States of the Union. It is not well
to estimate men before their work is done,
but with Councilman in Boston, Flexner
in New York and Barker in Chicago, Mary-
land has no need to blush for the sons she
has sent out from her border: and when
Oxford wants a Regius professor of medi-
cine and comes to Maryland to select him
we feel that little is left that may shed
honor on a profession already so highly
honored.

"I dare not leave this period without
emphasizing the part which the State
Board of Medical Examiners has played in
uplifting the profession. They have acted
as the bulwark against which greed of gain
and petty commercialism have beat in vain
in trying to inundate the profession.
Nathan R. Smith.

"I cannot close without reference to two
men who have shed such luster on medi-
cine in Maryland as to compel mention.
Two years before that meeting at Annapo-
lis there was born in the town of Cornish,
in Connecticut, a male child who was des-
tined to pass through a long life and
reach a poistion of high honor and prefer-
ment in his profession. Educated in New
England, a short stay in Virginia seemed
to have inclined him to the South. When
George McClellan founded the Jefferson
Medical College he turned to this young
man, then less than 30 years old, to take
the chair of anatomy. For two years he
continued in the place, but in 1827 he left
